Posts.Content: sfhusb wrote: While these past few months have been very rough, I thought I'd pass along one little victory we've had over Xeloda side effects.   My wife has been on Xeloda for almost two years now, and over the last few weeks the hand foot syndrome has become unbearable (burning, redness, dry cracking skin).  Rather than quit the drug, our onc suggested trying a 7mg nicotine patch.   While it didn't help with the dryness and cracking, the redness and burning sensation went away within 24 hours. I know there have been some clincal trials on this but haven't been able to find any results.   Thought this information might be useful for anyone having bad HFS, as always probably best to check with your Onc before trying. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: Xeloda and Nicotine Patch sfhusb PJB

Posts.Content: Feb 14, 2011 11:44AM sfhusb wrote: Susan, Amy to your earlier question, my wife is definately a half-emptier while i'm full glass (example, whenever the doorbell rings, she starts with the assumption that its a magazine subscription solicitor at the door, i start with the assumption that its Publishers Clearinghouse with a $25 million check (in reality its usually a neighber stopping by to report a broken sprinklerhead).  MJ thanks for the offer to penpal.  I'll pass your offer along, hopefully she'll take you up on the offer.  I'll post back after our onc appt on Wed to let you know how it goes.   BTW, what does the "D" abbreviation stand for in DH (I was assuming it was Damn Husband :) ).
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: sfhusb wrote: Hi all, this is my first time posting to this forum.  My wife was diagnosed 10 years ago at age 32 with stage IIb and just last June her breast cancer returned with multiple tumors in her spine, pelvis and femur.  While she had an amazing response to Xeloda, she's had to go off the drug due to side-effects (the usual hand/foot issues, but also severe stomach problems).  Since being off the drug we've been going to the Oncs office monthly for serum marker tests.  I understand that the doc needs to do this to make sure we don't need to go back on a reduced dose of Xeloda or try a different drug, but these monthly tests have been the hardest thing, psychologically for my wife to deal with.  In her words, we're living month-to-month.  She's sick with worry getting her blood drawn, wondering what the results will show, stresses even more waiting for the doctors call, and even when we get the good news that the markers are down or stable, she starts stressing immediately about the next draw.  I understand why she stresses, I want to find a way to help her deal with this, but I haven't a clue how to do that.  So I thought I'd throw the question out to the group for advice. I tried to get my wife to visit this site, but she doesn't want to particpate in online boards, and support groups are out of the question (she thinks they'll just depress her more).  So with your help, i'll summarize the advice I receive here and pass it along.  Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 06:52AM sfhusb wrote: Thanks Becky, well said!  I'll just have to fight my instincts to give pep talks.  This disease sucks in so many ways, and I'll never truly be able to understand what's she's going through, i can't even fathom the pain and ups and downs of tests, results, procedures.  From this side, I just feel so helpless, I want to find some way to make her feel better, about anything really, but I'm at a complete loss for how to do that. I'll have to convince myself that to just listen is the most I can do right now.  thank you.
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 07:01AM sfhusb wrote: Heidi,  Thanks for your message.  I'm actually an analyst be trade (and a closet statistics geek) I've drawn my wife several distribution curves to illustrate just how meaningless a mean and median can be.  The example I always bring up is, to use the the average survival time for her case would be just as useless as averaging everyone's jean size in the country and manufacturing just one size-fits all jean (she hates that example). Pain meds has been another sticking point between us (she tells her friends that i'm a pill pusher), her big concern is that she doesn't want to become addicted to narcotics, i've shared with her the research that shows that when patients take narcotics for pain they rarely become addicted because the drug goes to the pain center of the brain not the pleasure center.  I don't think she's listening to me.  She also doesn't like the way the drugs make her feel (which I can understand) and she's very eager to get off narcotics so she can drive, so she can be more independant.  We've weaned her off the fentanyl patch and take dilaudid as needed...
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: Feb 13, 2011 10:18AM sfhusb wrote: Thanks Lowrider, we're meeting with the Onc Wed. so i'll ask about anti-anxiety meds like ativan to help easy the anxiety.  Amy, i've tried an experiment over the last 24 hours of just listening per your suggestion (no pep talk!) I think its helping, i'm starting to understand that at times she just wants to lash-out at someone or anything.  In the past I tried to fix this by being upbeat, but listening is definately better. Unfortunately she's not letting me off the hook that easily.  There are questions that come up every time she gets down/frustrated.  Why is this happening to me? (i say i don't know), How am i supposed to live mont-to-month with these serum marker tests?  (the question that started this topic).  How do I answer this last question without launching into a positive pep-talk?
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: Mar 12, 2012 10:19AM sfhusb wrote: My wife switched to Xgeva three months ago.  We had some problems with the hospital keeping it in stock (due to high cost/dose).  As far as side effects, she's had virtually none.  On Zometa she had flu like symptoms the day after as well as some fatigue, on Xgeva its a simple subcutaneous shot in the stomach, much better than the IV stick for Zometa.  Hope that helps.
Posts.Title: Denosumab (Xgeva) vs Zometa Sweetanimo sfhusb

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 04:42AM sfhusb wrote: Amy, Susan, thanks so much for your thougtful replies.  Amy to your questions (i haven't figured out how to configure the footer here to reflect that i'm the caregiver and then post stats) but here we go: Initial diagnosis in 3/2000 with stage IIb, BRCA2+ 16/30 postive nodes ER+/PR+ HER2-.  She initially did AC/Taxol, bilateral mastectomy, oopherectomy, radiation, Tamoxifan for 5 years, then Aromisan until stage IV diagnosis 6/2010. Back in January 2010, she was in a pilates ball class and fell off her ball injuring her back, but instead of getting better she got worse and worse, we thought she had a ruptured disc (her symptoms didn't seem to match bone mets, pain was constantly moving around, and it all started with the fall in class) in June we did an MRI that showed the multiple lesions on her spine and pelvis.  Her biopsy revealed ER- PR+ (10%) HER2-.  She had several weeks of radiation to her spine and hip and femur, follwed by Zometa infusions every 28 days, the onc put her back on Tamox since she "failed" while on Aromisan. We did 4 courses of Xeloda before the side effects got to be too severe (it was the constant diaharea not the hand/foot thing that caused the doc to take her off). Since her markers continued to fall, her PET/CT scans have shown that the disease isn't progressing, but last month her cancer markers went up for the first time since she started treatment.  I understand the markers arent perfect, but I guess its the only way to know, abscent constant scaning to know how long she can stay off a chemo treatment.  Our biggest challenge now is dealing with month-to-month issue as well as pain mgmt.  I've tried to get her on the board, I print out the posts from that amazing member who's now 18 or 19 years into bone mets and still doing great, but she gets furious at me for sharing these stories with her, telling me that i'm not facing reality and that those stories are of the "outliers."  While she might be right, and in the words of our onc, this crappy disease is very heterogenous so its really unfair to look at stats.  Unfotunately we had a bad experience with a therapist back in 2000 when she was first diagnosed.  If there's anyone here from the bay area that knows of a good one please private message me.  Maybe i can convince her to give it another shot.   While this board may only be helpful to her by proxy, I spend a lot of my evening after she goes to sleep reading through everyone's post.  For some reason it gives me lots of comfort and I sincerley thank all of you for that.
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: Feb 11, 2011 06:20AM sfhusb wrote: Hey Becky Thanks for the kind words.  On your question, the oncologists(we've been to three, one local and two teaching hospitals)are of the opinion that any positive result on either estrogen or progesteron warrants hormonal therapy.  Maybe some anti-anxiety drugs would help, I'll talk to her docs about that.   I guess you're right, i'll just have to wait for her to come around to getting some help talking things through.  I'm trying to do my best, but my "power of positive thinking" pep-talks seem to be doing more harm then good.   Any suggestions from the group as to what they'd like to hear from their spouse or caregiver when you're feeling particularly down or discouraged?
Posts.Title: How to Deal with Monthly Cancer Markers sfhusb susan_02143

Posts.Content: sfhusb wrote: My wife just had her first infusion of carboplatin last week (part of a clinical trial including ABT-888 (Velaparib)), and she's in extreme pain from her wrist to her mid-forearm, the iv was place on the back of her hand.  Our onc. thinks that her veins just aren't tolerating the chemo very well and advised a port, but my wife is hesitant.  She's tiny, only 95lbs, and thinks that the port will be too noticeable.  We heard someone mention a new, smaller port that was just coming on the market a year ago and was wondering if anyone has heard anything about it... thanks in advance. Posts.Title: Smaller Ports? sfhusb Adnerb

Posts.Content: sfhusb wrote: We just recieved the pathology report from my wife's liver biopsy (new to liver mets as of this month, prior bone only).  At original diagnosis in 2000 she was 90% ER and PR +, then in 2010 just ER +, and now triple negative, Has this change happened to anyone else?  We're feeling a little freaked out now. In good news, we just enrolled in the Velaparib (ABT-888) trial at USC, hoping this can bring us some stability. Log in to post a reply
Posts.Title: From ER/PR+ to Triple Negative sfhusb Latte

Posts.Content: Aug 12, 2013 03:15PM sfhusb wrote: Thanks RangerMom, Latte,  I have a call into the doc to see if he'll prescribe Emend.  Have you had any other SE's?  She's struggling to focus, and has had changes to her sense of taste (can't drink any bottled water, "after taking Velaparib it taste's weird").
Posts.Title: From ER/PR+ to Triple Negative sfhusb Latte

Posts.Content: Aug 16, 2013 11:09AM sfhusb wrote: Thanks Latte, I don't know why the MDs didn't think of that, but my wife does have very low blood pressure, I also noticed that lowering of blood pressure is a reported SE with Velaparib.   Will investigate pronto.   We had to take her off the drug this week as the side effects were unbearable.  They're going to lower the dose to 300mg 2x/day, hopefully with some meds to increase her BP she'll tolerate the new dose.  A million thanks for your insights.
Posts.Title: From ER/PR+ to Triple Negative sfhusb Latte

Posts.Content: Aug 11, 2013 08:13PM sfhusb wrote: Sorry, We've been out of touch, we just got back from USC.  Our Onc said that about 10% of tumors in Stage IV will evolve to triple neg from ER or PR +,  guess we just got lucky to be in the 10% .  We started the ABT-888 (Velaparib) trial this last Thursday, which has been a very difficult drug for my wife.  She's on a very high dose (400mg twice per day) she's been suffering from bad nausea and vomiting, dizzyness.  We've tried Zofran (which as worked in the past), compazine, and nothing is working.  Anyone have any suggestions?
